THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT BY BEATRIX POTTER
Watercolor of the Rabbit family without clothes sitting in the roots of a tree
Text Page.
ONCE upon a time there were four little Rabbits, and their names were— Flopsy, Mopsy, Cotton-tail, and Peter.
They lived with their Mother in a sand-bank, underneath the root of a very big fir tree.
Text Page.

"NOW, my dears,'' said old Mrs. Rabbit one morning, "you may go into the fields or down the lane, but don't go into Mr. McGregor's garden: your Father had an accident there; he was put in a pie by Mrs. McGregor.''
Watercolor of Mrs. Rabbit giving baskets to the little rabbits and Peter is in the foreground.
Blank Page.
Blank Page.
Watercolor of Mrs. Rabbit buttoning Peter Rabbit's jacket.
Text Page.
"NOW run along, and don't get into mischief. I am going out.''
Text Page.
THEN old Mrs. Rabbit took a basket and her umbrella, and went through the wood to the baker's. She bought a loaf of brown bread and five currant buns.
Watercolor of Mrs. Rabbit with basket, umbrella, and cloak going through the forest.
Blank Page.
Blank Page.
Watercolor of the rabbits, Flopsy, Mopsy and Cotton-tail gathering blackberries along with magpies.
Text Page.
FLOPSY, Mopsy, and Cotton- tail, who were good little bunnies, went down the lane to gather blackberries;
Text Page.
BUT Peter, who was very naughty, ran straight away to Mr. McGregor's garden, and squeezed under the gate!
Watercolor of Peter the rabbit sliding under a gate to get into Mr. McGregor's garden
Blank Page.
Blank Page.
Watercolor of Peter the rabbit munching on radishes in Mr. McGregor's garden with a robin sitting on a stoop
Text page.
FIRST he ate some lettuces and some French beans; and then he ate some radishes;
Text Page.
AND then, feeling rather sick, he went to look for some parsley.
Watercolor of Peter Rabbit feeling full amidst potted plants holding his belly
Blank Page. Blank Page. Watercolor of Peter Rabbit happening upon Mr. McGregor digging in his garden. Text Page.
BUT round the end of a cucumber frame, whom should he meet but Mr. McGregor!
Text Page.

MR. McGREGOR was on his hands and knees planting out young cabbages, but he jumped up and ran after Peter, waving a rake and calling out, "Stop thief!'' Watercolor of Mr. McGregor chasing Peter Rabbit with a rake. Blank Page. Blank Page. Watercolor of a robin, Peter Rabbit's lost shoe and cabbage. Text Page.
PETER was most dreadfully frightened; he rushed all over the garden, for he had forgotten the way back to the gate.
He lost one of his shoes among the cabbages, and the other shoe amongst the potatoes. Text Page.

AFTER losing them, he ran on four legs and went faster, so that I think he might have got away altogether if he had not unfortunately run into a gooseberry net, and got caught by the large buttons on his jacket. It was a blue jacket with brass buttons, quite new. Watercolor of Peter Rabbit caught in a gooseberry net with his blue jacket. Blank Page. Blank Page. Watercolor of Peter Rabbit caught in the gooseberry net with blue jacket, friendly sparrows speaking with him. Text Page.
PETER gave himself up for lost, and shed big tears; but his sobs were overheard by some friendly sparrows, who flew to him in great excitement, and implored him to exert himself. Text Page.

MR. McGREGOR came up with a sieve, which he intended to pop upon the top of Peter; but Peter wriggled out just in time, leaving his jacket behind him. Watercolor of the sparrows and Peter Rabbit, without jacket trying to escape Mr. McGregor's sieve. Blank Page. Blank Page. Watercolor of Peter Rabbit jumping into a water bucket. Text Page.
AND rushed into the tool- shed, and jumped into a can. It would have been a beautiful thing to hide in, if it had not had so much water in it. Text Page.
MR. McGREGOR was quite sure that Peter was somewhere in the tool- shed, perhaps hidden underneath a flower-pot. He began to turn them over carefully, looking under each.

Presently Peter sneezed— "Kertyschoo!'' Mr. McGregor was after him in no time, Watercolor of Mr. McGregor looking for Peter under planting pots. Peter Rabbit's ears stick out of the water bucket amidst shovels and brooms. Blank Page. Blank Page. Watercolor of Peter Rabbit jumping out the window upsetting three geraniums and Mr. McGregor's boot coming after him. Text Page.

AND tried to put his foot upon Peter, who jumped out of a window, upsetting three plants. The window was too small for Mr. McGregor, and he was tired of running after Peter. He went back to his work. Text Page.
PETER sat down to rest; he was out of breath and trembling with fright, and he had not the least idea which way to go. Also he was very damp with sitting in that can.

After a time he began to wander about, going lippity— lippity—not very fast, and looking all around. Watercolor of Peter Rabbit catching his breath and a sparrow sits behind him. Blank Page. Blank Page. Watercolor of Peter Rabbit crying and an old mouse talking to him. Text Page.
HE found a door in a wall; but it was locked, and there was no room for a fat little rabbit to squeeze underneath.

An old mouse was running in and out over the stone doorstep, carrying peas and beans to her family in the wood. Peter asked her the way to the gate, but she had such a large pea in her mouth that she could not answer. She only shook her head at him. Peter began to cry. Text Page.

THEN he tried to find his way straight across the garden, but he became more and more puzzled. Presently, he came to a pond where Mr. McGregor filled his water-cans. A white cat was staring at some gold-fish; she sat very, very still, but now and then the tip of her tail twitched as if it were alive. Peter thought it best to go away without speaking to her; he had heard about cats from his cousin, little Benjamin Bunny. Watercolor of Peter Rabbit coming up on a white cat next to a water-can staring into a pond. Blank Page. Blank Page. Watercolor of Peter Rabbit sitting in a wheelbarrow staring at Mr. McGregor as he hoes his onions. Text Page.

HE went back towards the tool-shed, but suddenly, quite close to him, he heard the noise of a hoe—scr-r-ritch, scratch, scratch, scritch. Peter scuttered underneath the bushes. But presently, as nothing happened, he came out, and climbed upon a wheelbarrow, and peeped over. The first thing he saw was Mr. McGregor hoeing onions. His back was turned towards Peter, and beyond him was the gate! Text Page.
PETER got down very quietly off the wheelbarrow, and started running as fast as he could go, along a straight walk behind some black-currant bushes.

Mr. McGregor caught sight of him at the corner, but Peter did not care. He slipped underneath the gate, and was safe at last in the wood outside the garden. Watercolor of Mr. McGregor running after Peter Rabbit as he dives under the gate with sparrows looking down upon him. Blank Page. Blank Page. Watercolor of Peter Rabbit's blue jacket and shoes hung up on a stake as a scarecrow. Blackbirds and sparrows are not frightened. Text Page.
MR. McGREGOR hung up the little jacket and the shoes for a scare-crow to frighten the blackbirds. Text Page. PETER never stopped running or looked behind him till he got home to the big fir-tree.

He was so tired that he flopped down upon the nice soft sand on the floor of the rabbit-hole, and shut his eyes. His mother was busy cooking; she wondered what he had done with his clothes. It was the second little jacket and pair of shoes that Peter had lost in a fortnight! Watercolor of Mother Rabbit cooking and Peter Rabbit sleeping on the floor of the rabbit-hole; Flopsy, Mopsy, and Cotton-tail are in the background. Blank Page. Blank Page. Text Page.
I AM sorry to say that Peter was not very well during the evening.
His mother put him to bed, and made some camomile tea; and she gave a dose of it to Peter!

"One table-spoonful to be taken at bed-time.'' Watercolor of Flopsy, Mopsy, and Cotton-tail watching Mother Rabbit make camomile tea for Peter who sits in bed. Blank Page. Blank Page. Watercolor of Flopsy, Mopsy, and Cotton-tail Rabbits sitting around a bowl of milk and basket of blackberries eating.
BUT Flopsy, Mopsy, and Cotton-tail had bread and milk and blackberries, for supper.
THE END
